example.label: bidumsaamegiella
example.translation: the Pite Saami language

example.label: intonationDropEx
example.translation: It is autumn and we will slaughter the reindeer bulls

example.label: utteranceFinalDevoicing1
example.translation: ‘They have had a good summer.’

example.label: uncountableEx1
example.translation: ‘In this shed we had flour and sugar and clothing and other food.’

example.label: uncountableEx2
example.translation: ‘But cheese, (it’s) definitely tasty in coffee.’

example.label: nom1
example.translation: ‘Then a big moose arrives.’

example.label: nom2
example.translation: ‘And then one makes a fire.’

example.label: nom3
example.translation: ‘I have a car.’ (lit.: ‘at-me is car’)

example.label: gen1
example.translation: ‘What is the name of that person who you are talking with?’

example.label: gen2
example.translation: ‘to smoke (something) inside a hut’

example.label: acc1
example.translation: ‘Then I have to take out the lungs, the liver and such things.’

example.label: acc2
example.translation: ‘I give food to all the reindeer.’

example.label: acc3
example.translation: ‘Yes, and we slept under that for a night.’

example.label: ill1
example.translation: ‘Some reindeer don’t come into the corral.’

example.label: ill2
example.translation: ‘My father said to some friend...’

example.label: ill4
example.translation: ‘Give (one) to Josh, too!’

example.label: ill5
example.translation: ‘You are my maternal uncle.’ (lit.: you are maternal uncle to me)

example.label: iness1
example.translation: ‘Well, what more did you do in Áhkkabakkte?’

example.label: iness2
example.translation: ‘Sálvo Creek is in the valley.’

example.label: iness3
example.translation: ‘The Saami man has a dog.’ (lit.: at Saami is dog)

example.label: elat1
example.translation: ‘I loosen the stomach from the liver.’

example.label: elat2b
example.translation: ‘You come from America.’

example.label: elat5
example.translation: ‘I will ask Edgar.’

example.label: elat6
example.translation: ‘I have a headache.’ (lit.: ‘I am from head’)

example.label: elat3
example.translation: ‘I don’t like that (made) of fresh blood.’

example.label: elat4
example.translation: ‘These are sewn out of furless leather.’

example.label: elat5b
example.translation: ‘The hut has been built by children.’

example.label: elat7
example.translation: ‘I am bigger than Sven.’

example.label: com1
example.translation: ‘But were you allowed to speak the Saami language with your siblings?’

example.label: com1b
example.translation: ‘Do you take your coffee with sugar or without sugar?’

example.label: com2
example.translation: ‘Now one drives to Örnvik by car, then by boat over Lake Tjeggelvas.’

example.label: com3
example.translation: ‘Sven is as old as Inger.’ (lit.: Sven is one age with Inger)

example.label: abess1
example.translation: ‘Do you take your coffee with sugar or without sugar?’

example.label: abess2
example.translation: ‘You are heartless now.’

example.label: ess1a
example.translation: ‘I become a dog.’

example.label: ess1b
example.translation: ‘Ice becomes water.’

example.label: ess2
example.translation: ‘Yonder birch is called a boat.’

example.label: ess3
example.translation: ‘He swims like a fish.’

example.label: ess4
example.translation: ‘He swims like a fish.’

example.label: possSuffix1
example.translation: ‘My father is checking if there are any unmarked calves.’

example.label: possSuffix5
example.translation: ‘Well then she said “well, say hello to your mother and your father”.’

example.label: possSuffixParse1
example.translation: ‘my father’

example.label: possSuffixParse2
example.translation: ‘to your (pl) mother’

example.label: possSuffixParse3
example.translation: ‘to your (pl) father’

example.label: noPossSuffix1
example.translation: ‘And then it was our paternal aunt Karin.’

example.label: demProWithNonHumanReferent1
example.translation: ‘So sometimes we sold those.’

example.label: demProTextDeixis
example.translation: ‘Oh! That’s no problem.’ (lit.: that makes nothing)

example.label: reflPron1
example.translation: ‘I talk about myself.’

example.label: reflPron3
example.translation: ‘I myself am Saami.’

example.label: reflPron2
example.translation: ‘(You) yourself have learned.’

example.label: QpronounHUMex1
example.translation: ‘Well, who did you go with?’

example.label: QpronounHUMex2
example.translation: ‘Whose shoes are these?’

example.label: QpronounNoHUMex
example.translation: ‘What do you want?’

example.label: QpronounDEMGeneralEx1
example.translation: ‘What is that made of?’

example.label: QpronounDEMGeneralEx2
example.translation: ‘Well which (people) were in Ákkabakkte?’

example.label: QpronounDEMGeneralEx3
example.translation: ‘Which (kind of) blood was it?’

example.label: QpronounDEMGeneralEx4
example.translation: ‘Which (kinds of) fish did you buy?’

example.label: QpronounDEMGeneralEx5
example.translation: ‘And then he is also checking a bit which reindeer bulls they should also slaughter.’

example.label: QpronounDEMLimitedEx1
example.translation: ‘At which of the two places have you been?’

example.label: QpronounDEMLimitedEx2
example.translation: ‘Which two are you talking about?’

example.label: otherQpronounEx1
example.translation: ‘Where did you pick them?’

example.label: otherQpronounEx2
example.translation: ‘How does one say ‘reta’?’

example.label: otherQpronounEx3
example.translation: ‘How far it was, when one was home, I don’t know’

example.label: adjEx1
example.translation: ‘It is a black reindeer and a white head.’

example.label: adjEx2
example.translation: ‘Fish is such tasty food.’

example.label: adjEx3
example.translation: ‘that white reindeer’

example.label: adjEx4
example.translation: ‘And it has been a really good summer.’

example.label: adjNPheadEx1
example.translation: ‘I eat the red one.’

example.label: adjNPheadEx2
example.translation: ‘The black ones are tasty.’

example.label: adjNPheadEx3
example.translation: ‘That beautiful one can (speak) the Saami language.’ (referring to a girl)

example.label: adjNPheadEx4
example.translation: ‘It is a quite beautiful one, it, it is a white reindeer.’ (referring to a reindeer)

example.label: adjPredEx1
example.translation: ‘The mitten is black.’

example.label: adjPredEx2
example.translation: ‘The mittens are black.’

example.label: adjPredEx3
example.translation: ‘The reindeer are so fat and beautiful.’

example.label: compATTRADJex1
example.translation: ‘warmer weather’

example.label: superlATTRADJex1
example.translation: ‘So then it’s the oldest place.’

example.label: compATTRADJex2
example.translation: ‘I kiss the more beautiful one.’ (referring to ‘beautiful girl’)

example.label: superlATTRADJex2
example.translation: ‘The reindeer were farthest away.’ (lit.: in the farthest one (place))

example.label: comparingNPsEx1
example.translation: ‘Sven is as old as Inger.’ (lit.: Sven is one old with Inger)

example.label: comparingNPsEx2
example.translation: ‘We two are the same age.’ (lit.: we are one old)

example.label: comparingNPsEx3
example.translation: ‘Inger is bigger than a mountain.’

example.label: comparingNPsEx5
example.translation: ‘This was probably the absolute oldest made.’

example.label: smallADJex1
example.translation: ‘Yes, I also remember when I was a small child.’

example.label: smallADJex3
example.translation: ‘only one thumb, and small gloves, these here’

example.label: smallADJex4
example.translation: ‘Dogs are small.’

example.label: smallADJex5
example.translation: ‘This is in the house, in the little house.’

example.label: smallADJex6
example.translation: ‘And I saw a little lingonberry there.’

example.label: quantEx1
example.translation: ‘Did you see many long-leggers?’ (referring to moose)

example.label: quantEx2a
example.translation: ‘Every day we ate fish.’

example.label: quantEx2b
example.translation: ‘And then one takes a knife and cuts some holes.’

example.label: quantEx3
example.translation: ‘All people are in Arjeplog.’

example.label: quantEx4
example.translation: ‘I have a little hair.’

example.label: quantifierEx3
example.translation: ‘I give all the reindeer food.’

example.label: quantifierEx6
example.translation: ‘Shall I put in more?’

example.label: quantifierEx7
example.translation: ‘Go throw those heads and all that over there.’

example.label: quantifierEx8
example.translation: ‘Say something that I should say.’

example.label: noneEx1
example.translation: ‘I don’t have any hair.’ (lit.: on me isn’t a single hair)

example.label: noneEx2
example.translation: ‘if one didn’t know any people’

example.label: noneEx3
example.translation: ‘One didn’t say anything at all.’

example.label: quantifierEx4a
example.translation: ‘There is much meat.’ (lit.: meat is much)

example.label: quantifierEx4b
example.translation: ‘There are many pieces of meat.’ (lit.: meat pieces are many)

example.label: demonstrativeAdjectivesEx2
example.translation: ‘when we had driven that ‘Grålle’ tractor’

example.label: demonstrativeAdjectivesEx1
example.translation: ‘We pulled those fish here with a sled.’

example.label: demonstrativeAdjectivesEx3
example.translation: ‘But that pine tree over there, how short and thick!’

example.label: complexNumEx1
example.translation: ‘... how it was here seventy years ago.’

example.label: complexNumEx3
example.translation: ‘She is eighty-seven years old.’

example.label: complexNumEx2
example.translation: ‘Then he skied and slew forty-eight wolves with a spear.’

example.label: complexNumEx4
example.translation: ‘He lived in the nineteen-hundreds, at the beginning.’

example.label: numeralEx3b
example.translation: ‘I give food to three reindeer.’

example.label: numeralEx3
example.translation: ‘So then it’s two.’

example.label: numeralEx2
example.translation: ‘And it is the fourth of April today.’

example.label: numeralEx4
example.translation: ‘And the third one then goes to Stutja.’ (referring to a fishing net)

example.label: numOneEx1
example.translation: ‘We got one fish.’

example.label: numOneEx2
example.translation: ‘But I shot one.’

example.label: veryFirstEx
example.translation: ‘You know, I shot my very first long-legger.’ (referring to a moose)

example.label: inflectionalCatsVerbsEx1
example.translation: ‘And then they go together when they are going to kill some animal.’

example.label: inflectionalCatsVerbsEx2
example.translation: ‘Josh and I were picking blueberries outside.’

example.label: inflectionalCatsVerbsEx3
example.translation: ‘Throw a ski-pole to me!’

example.label: presentEx1
example.translation: ‘Now it’s only the sun which melts the snow.’

example.label: presentEx2
example.translation: ‘I take the bobber and then I tie the net to that bobber and I say to my friend...’

example.label: presentEx3
example.translation: ‘And then after that you’ll drive to Västerås.’

example.label: imperativeEx1
example.translation: ‘Well, say something about this ‘Luoddauvre’!’

example.label: imperativeEx2
example.translation: ‘Do that now!’

example.label: potentialEx1
example.translation: ‘Well then I say we should obviously go.’

example.label: potentialEx2
example.translation: ‘Oh no, I’ll probably have to take off some clothes.’

example.label: potentialEx3
example.translation: ‘Perhaps he’ll make some coffee.’

example.label: potentialEx4
example.translation: ‘Perhaps you could make some coffee.’

example.label: potentialEx5
example.translation: ‘Please hear what I am saying!’

example.label: futureTenseEx1
example.translation: ‘Well how are you going to reach it with that?’

example.label: futureTenseEx2
example.translation: ‘Then I will tell a story.’

example.label: futureTenseEx3
example.translation: ‘How many days are you going to be there?’

example.label: perfectEx1
example.translation: ‘But I am cutting out the stomach, I have knotted the esophagus in the neck.’

example.label: perfectEx3
example.translation: ‘They have died, only my mother is still living now.’

example.label: inflectionalCatsVerbsEx2b
example.translation: ‘Josh and I were picking blueberries outside.’

example.label: ADVverbsEx1
example.translation: ‘She walks while laughing.’

example.label: ADVverbsEx2
example.translation: ‘I write while listening.’

example.label: connegEx1
example.translation: ‘I don’t feel like taking the rumen fat and stuff at this time.’

example.label: connegEx2
example.translation: ‘Well Henning didn’t get sick after he had been freezing like that.’

example.label: negImpEx1
example.translation: ‘Don’t hit!’ (said to a child)

example.label: passEx4
example.translation: ‘That house was built by Nils.’

example.label: passEx1a
example.translation: ‘And that is different as it has been sewn like that.’

example.label: passEx1b
example.translation: ‘But these reindeer have not been marked.’

example.label: cliticBE
example.translation: ‘You also have Fjällräven pants on.’

example.label: beVerbPRFex2
example.translation: ‘But I haven’t been in school during the summer.’

example.label: derivedADVsEx1
example.translation: ‘You have to take it carefully.’

example.label: derivedADVsEx2
example.translation: ‘We definitely lived pretty well with the fishing, too.’ Note that ganska is a nonce borrowing from language contactSwedish; cf.Swedish ganska ‘quite’.

example.label: ADVsEx1
example.translation: ‘They didn’t only make cheese from reindeer milk.’

example.label: ADVsEx3
example.translation: ‘Maybe Edgar knows.’

example.label: ADVsEx3b
example.translation: ‘And then one puts twigs on the other side, too.’

example.label: ADVsEx5
example.translation: ‘This was definitely the absolute oldest place from the old days.’

example.label: particleEx6
example.translation: 12pt‘Were you allowed to speak the Saami language there?’ nä ij gal i-ttjiv åtjo no neg/3sg.prs actually neg-1sg.pst be.allowed/conneg12pt‘No, actually no, I wasn’t allowed to.’

example.label: ADVsEx2
example.translation: ‘We were too young.’

example.label: Qpart1
example.translation: ‘Are you hungry?’ (lit.: are you hungering)

example.label: Qpart2
example.translation: ‘Do you have something, memories?’

example.label: Qpart3
example.translation: ‘Well, do you drink coffee?’

example.label: postpositionEx1
example.translation: ‘and to cut meat into the coffee’

example.label: postpositionEx2
example.translation: ‘And then the school children went over that by kick-sled.’

example.label: prepositionEx1
example.translation: ‘and ribbon, purchased ribbon around that’

example.label: prepositionEx2
example.translation: ‘So we received more than four Swedish crowns per kilogram back then.’

example.label: conjunctionEx1
example.translation: ‘We got milk, butter, cheese and meat from these.’

example.label: conjunctionEx2
example.translation: ‘The reindeer are so fat and beautiful.’

example.label: conjunctionEx3
example.translation: ‘But I believe when I was fourteen or fifteen years (old)...’

example.label: conjunctionEx4
example.translation: ‘Do you take coffee with or without sugar?’

example.label: conjunctionEx5
example.translation: ‘And nowadays no one lives or resides there.’

example.label: conjunctionEx6
example.translation: ‘We had or ate blueberries and cloudberries.’

example.label: particleEx3
example.translation: 12pt‘Well hello, Henning!’ nå buris dä well hello then12pt‘Well hello there!’ nå guste dån bådá well from.where 2sg.nom come/2sg.prs12pt‘Well where are you coming from?’

example.label: particleEx4
example.translation: 12pt‘And then my dog Rahka.’ nå duv bena aj well 2sg.gen dog/nom.sg also12pt‘Ok, your dog, too.’

example.label: noEx1
example.translation: 12pt‘...so then we were able to, Josh and I were able to ski up to this10pt here Big Point.’ nå well12pt‘That’s all.’

example.label: particleEx7
example.translation: 12pt‘‘tjåddjåk’, no, it’s not ‘tjåddjåk’.’ jå lä tjåddjåk yes be/3sg.prs esophagus/nom.sg12pt‘Yes, it’s ‘tjåddjåk’.’

example.label: NMLZ2ex1
example.translation: ‘Did you see some moose?’

example.label: nominalizerEx1
example.translation: ‘if one has faith’

example.label: passEx2
example.translation: ‘Children have built the hut.’

example.label: passEx3
example.translation: ‘The hut has been built by children.’

example.label: derivADJex1
example.translation: ‘That person is evil.’

example.label: derivADJex2
example.translation: ‘evil person’

example.label: VCex1
example.translation: ‘Get some paper!’

example.label: VCex2
example.translation: ‘The name of that mountain is Sállvo.’

example.label: VCex3
example.translation: ‘It doesn’t matter, I’ll get that later.’

example.label: VCex4
example.translation: ‘If wolves had entered the reindeer herd, they went and got him.’

example.label: VCex5
example.translation: ‘The reindeer can attack you.’ (lit: ‘come upon you’)

example.label: VCex5a
example.translation: ‘Then we have to mark those calves now in the autumn.’

example.label: VCex6
example.translation: ‘I haven’t heard that at all.’

example.label: VCex7
example.translation: ‘One cannot really have too big of a fire.’

example.label: VCex8
example.translation: ‘I have been able to speak Saami.’

example.label: NPstructureEx0
example.translation: ‘And then I see Lake Tjeggelvas.’

example.label: NPstructureEx1
example.translation: ‘And then that reindeer herd drowned.’

example.label: NPstructureEx2
example.translation: ‘These Skailes’ reindeer herd drowned.’

example.label: NPstructureGenNPex1
example.translation: ‘And one made blood dumplings.’

example.label: NPstructureEx3
example.translation: ‘There were so many reindeer.’ (lit.: ‘so much reindeer’)

example.label: NPstructureEx4
example.translation: ‘Then we had two big moose.’ (lit.: ‘long-leggers’)

example.label: NPstructureEx6
example.translation: ‘And the third one is then placed at Stutja.’ (referring to ‘fishing net’)

example.label: adjNPheadEx3repeat
example.translation: ‘That beautiful one can speak the Saami language.’

example.label: NPstructureEx8
example.translation: ‘I eat the red one.’

example.label: NPstructureProEx1
example.translation: ‘He fried those on a stick.’

example.label: NPstructureProEx2
example.translation: ‘I could open the door.’

example.label: NPstructureProEx3
example.translation: ‘I myself say it like that.’

example.label: NPstructureRelClEx1
example.translation: ‘These are gloves which one has in winter.’

example.label: ADVnounsEx1
example.translation: ‘I believe I went in the summer.’

example.label: ADVnounsEx2
example.translation: ‘And Henning had been home for a week.’

example.label: ADVnounsEx3
example.translation: ‘They themselves of course had milk and cheese.’

example.label: APstructureEx1
example.translation: ‘And we ate tasty food there.’

example.label: APstructureEx2
example.translation: ‘And it has been a really good summer.’

example.label: APstructureEx3
example.translation: ‘The child is young.’

example.label: APstructureEx4
example.translation: ‘Then the perch are so fat.’

example.label: APstructureEx5
example.translation: ‘Then two houses are there.’

example.label: APstructureEx6
example.translation: ‘You know, I shot my very first long-legger.’

example.label: APstructureEx7
example.translation: ‘Initially there was only one room.’

example.label: ADVadjectivesEx1
example.translation: ‘If one slaughtered them correctly, then one would take them out before one hung them up.’

example.label: AdvPex1
example.translation: ‘At that time it was, it went well.’

example.label: derivedADVsEx2repeat
example.translation: ‘We definitely lived quite well with the fishing, too.’

example.label: AdvPex2
example.translation: ‘But this one is obviously quite old.’

example.label: PPex2
example.translation: ‘I am standing on ‘Big Point’ in Västerfjäll.’

example.label: PPex3
example.translation: ‘I have to put water into that.’

example.label: PPex5
example.translation: ‘What are those on?’

example.label: PPex6
example.translation: ‘On which rock?’

example.label: ADVppEx1
example.translation: ‘Katarina and I used to play on that rock.’

example.label: intrans1
example.translation: ‘So I lay in the sled.’

example.label: monotrans1
example.translation: ‘Then one places the stick like this.’

example.label: ditrans1
example.translation: ‘I give food to several reindeer.’

example.label: monotrans2
example.translation: ‘And I also see this from the window from my house.’

example.label: standardConstOrder1
example.translation: ‘He thinks.’

example.label: standardConstOrder2
example.translation: ‘I see a bear.’

example.label: standardConstOrder3
example.translation: ‘The man gives the flower to the woman.’

example.label: deviantConstituentOrder1
example.translation: ‘First I’ll put out the net in Áktjuotjålbme.’

example.label: deviantConstituentOrder2
example.translation: ‘I use birchwood.’

example.label: deviantConstituentOrder4
example.translation: ‘Then I will show some pictures.’

example.label: missingNP1
example.translation: ‘(The reindeer) only has one antler.’

example.label: missingNP2
example.translation: ‘(The reindeer herder) will pull (the reindeer buck) out.’

example.label: missingNP3
example.translation: ‘I’ll put (the pole) there.’

example.label: missingNP4
example.translation: ‘And give (me) (a sausage), Eva-Karin!’

example.label: missingNP5
example.translation: 12pt‘and such beautiful weather!’ lä be/3sg.prs12pt‘yes, it is’ (lit.: ‘is’)

example.label: ConstOrderAdvVex1
example.translation: ‘And then a ptarmigan comes.’

example.label: ConstOrderAdvVex2
example.translation: ‘He grilled them then on a stick.’

example.label: ConstOrderAdvVex3
example.translation: ‘I didn’t remember.’

example.label: mouseText4
example.translation: ‘And there I saw a little lingonberry.’

example.label: mouseText5
example.translation: ‘I think (the mouse) had a pantry there.’

example.label: basicIntransDeclaratives1
example.translation: ‘One thinks, and...’

example.label: basicIntransDeclaratives2
example.translation: ‘I laugh.’

example.label: basicIntransDeclaratives3
example.translation: ‘The Skaile family’s reindeer herd drowned.’

example.label: passVoiceEx1
example.translation: ‘Children have built the hut.’

example.label: passVoiceEx2
example.translation: ‘That (hut) was built.’

example.label: passVoiceEx2b
example.translation: ‘This was probably the absolute oldest made.’

example.label: passVoiceEx3
example.translation: ‘The hut has been built by children.’

example.label: basicMonotransDeclaratives1
example.translation: ‘And I see snow here.’

example.label: basicMonotransDeclaratives2
example.translation: ‘The Saami keep the reindeer there in the summer.’

example.label: basicMonotransDeclaratives3
example.translation: ‘One puts out fishing nets in the evening.’

example.label: basicDitransDeclaratives1
example.translation: ‘I give food to three reindeer.’

example.label: basicDitransDeclaratives2
example.translation: ‘I give gloves to you.’

example.label: existential1
example.translation: ‘There is sorrel in the mountains, too.’ (lit.: there are sorrels...)

example.label: existential2
example.translation: ‘There isn’t a single tjårvebielle now.’

example.label: existential3
example.translation: ‘...with motor boats. There is no (word for) “motor” in the Saami language.’

example.label: copula1
example.translation: ‘Matthias was my maternal uncle.’

example.label: copula2
example.translation: ‘I am a Saami.’

example.label: copula3
example.translation: ‘The reindeer are so fat and beautiful.’

example.label: copula4
example.translation: ‘We two were in Fuordnak.’

example.label: copula5
example.translation: ‘And this is also (made) of cloth.’

example.label: copulaNr
example.translation: ‘And now it’s coffee (time).’

example.label: copula6
example.translation: ‘I have one child.’

example.label: copula7
example.translation: ‘And then we had cows.’

example.label: modalVerbs1
example.translation: ‘You all may drink water from that.’

example.label: modalVerbs2a
example.translation: ‘And then they had to start to feed (the reindeer).’

example.label: modalVerbs3
example.translation: ‘We can speak the Pite Saami language.’

example.label: modalVerbs4
example.translation: ‘I want to have fish.’

example.label: modalVerbs5
example.translation: ‘Then one obviously doesn’t want to go anywhere.’

example.label: future1
example.translation: ‘Then I will tell (you) a memory.’

example.label: future2
example.translation: ‘Yes, it’s a 3-year old reindeer buck, (he) will pull (it) out.’ Specifically, a vuoberis is a three-year-old reindeer buck, but the gloss has been shortened to save space.

example.label: future3
example.translation: ‘We will get that book.’

example.label: condClause1
example.translation: ‘If I choose Saami style, then I will pull the sternum like this.’

example.label: perfClause1
example.translation: ‘I was born there.’

example.label: perfClause2
example.translation: ‘Have you ever gone and accompanied (them) to Vistek?’

example.label: progClause1
example.translation: ‘But I’m cutting out the stomach.’

example.label: progClause2
example.translation: ‘Well, what is he studying?’ (lit.: reading)

example.label: negation1
example.translation: ‘I don’t believe so.’

example.label: negation2
example.translation: ‘There wasn’t any butter to buy at all.’

example.label: negation3
example.translation: ‘But they didn’t eat out of this.’

example.label: negation4
example.translation: ‘But you can’t have too big of a fire.’

example.label: negation5
example.translation: ‘I haven’t heard that at all.’

example.label: negation6
example.translation: ‘No, I haven’t eaten (it), but Josh has eaten (it).’

example.label: questionWordQ1
example.translation: ‘What are you saying?’

example.label: questionWordQ2
example.translation: ‘What then did you help (with)?’

example.label: questionWordQ3
example.translation: ‘Who did you go with?’

example.label: questionWordQ4
example.translation: ‘How long do you have those in the smoke hole for?’

example.label: questionWordQ6
example.translation: ‘How is it?’

example.label: questionWordQ7
example.translation: ‘Where are you coming from?’

example.label: questionWordQ8
example.translation: ‘Where did you pick those?’

example.label: nåQ1
example.translation: ‘Well what was Áhkkabákkte like when you were a child?’

example.label: polarQinversion1
example.translation: ‘Are you going to say more?’

example.label: polarQinversion2
example.translation: ‘Do you smoke?’

example.label: polarQinversion3
example.translation: ‘Was he alone or was Halvar also along?’

example.label: polarQinversion4
example.translation: ‘Were you allowed to speak Saami there?’

example.label: polarQinversion5
example.translation: ‘Have you ever drunk goat’s milk?’

example.label: polarQinversion6
example.translation: ‘Have you eaten meat there?’

example.label: impClause1
example.translation: ‘Say something about this Låddávvre!’

example.label: impClause2
example.translation: ‘Put the potato on the table!’

example.label: impClause3
example.translation: ‘Thank you (two)!’ (lit.: have thanks!)

example.label: impClause5
example.translation: ‘Go to sleep now!’

example.label: potSyntaxEx2
example.translation: ‘Well then I say we really should probably go.’

example.label: potSyntaxEx3
example.translation: ‘Oh no, I’ll probably have to take off some clothes.’

example.label: potSyntaxEx1
example.translation: ‘If he will perhaps make coffee.’

example.label: potSyntaxEx4
example.translation: ‘Perhaps you could make some coffee.’

example.label: coordination2
example.translation: ‘But they obviously didn’t eat out of that, but they had food, meat and so on in such things.’

example.label: ORcoordination1
example.translation: ‘Now this is the old house, or one says “the little house”.’

example.label: complementizer1
example.translation: ‘And then I say that I want to poop.’

example.label: complementizer2
example.translation: ‘But I know that there are greyling in the lake.’

example.label: complClauseJuxFin1
example.translation: ‘I believe there are big whitefish there.’

example.label: complClauseJuxFin2
example.translation: ‘But I think it was so nice to stay in tents.’

example.label: complClauseJuxFin3
example.translation: ‘But then I say we shot a moose.’

example.label: Qsubordination1
example.translation: ‘I don’t know when we’ll meet next time.’

example.label: Qsubordination2
example.translation: ‘I don’t understand what you’re saying.’

example.label: Qsubordination3
example.translation: ‘I know who she is.’

example.label: Qsubordination4
example.translation: ‘I don’t know how far it was to get home.’

example.label: complClauseJuxInf1
example.translation: ‘Well when did you start to take the boat from Örnvik?’

example.label: complClauseJuxInf2
example.translation: ‘And so they obviously had to start to feed, to transport the feed.’

example.label: complClauseJuxInf3
example.translation: ‘No, I forgot to take it along.’

example.label: complClauseJuxInf4
example.translation: ‘I am forgetting to say, when I did the perch...’

example.label: adverbialClause1
example.translation: ‘Well you have to back up then before I start the motor.’

example.label: adverbialClause2
example.translation: ‘Once (the farmers) had harvested, then they (the plants) came up.’

example.label: ADVverbsEx2repeat
example.translation: ‘I write while listening.’

example.label: relClause1
example.translation: ‘We had one bull with which we transported firewood.’

example.label: relClause2
example.translation: ‘...and the last snowmobiles which they had.’

example.label: relClause3
example.translation: ‘Those are times which have been.’ (i.e.: ‘those were the good old days’)

example.label: relClause4
example.translation: ‘We two who had come.’

example.label: relClause5
example.translation: ‘They were young people who were herding.’

example.label: relClause6
example.translation: ‘It was to you they came.’

example.label: relClause7
example.translation: ‘This is a milking bowl into which they milked reindeer.’

example.label: relClause8
example.translation: ‘But here was the pond whose name was, which was the name of that, this, our Arjeplog.’
